Official Website: http://squidsoft.net
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Humanity has just emerged from the lowest point in its collective history, and
the closest it has been to extinction since the advent of agriculture. By the
year 2304, the Coalition of humans and their alien allies the Jinu has spread
across the stars, and thought themselves powerful. But the Outsiders, an alien
empire occupying vast reaches of Rimward space, proved them wrong. First contact
between the two allies was severed, and suddenly humanity was alone. Then the
Outsiders attacked in force, and human planets and governments fell one by one.
                         It was the apocalypse.
But contrary to the beliefs of many, not all hope was lost. After five years,
a single starship, the Percival Lowell, returned from Rimward space, bringing
with it the means to nullify the Outsiders' greatest weapon. With this, and the
help of many other brave pilots, the occupying Outsiders were driven off human
               worlds and back to where they came from.
 Humanity is now trying to rebuild, and trying to regain what it has lost. The
Outsiders are finished with occupation, and now desire only to see humans
extinct.
New threats and new mysteries seem to appear every day. In the midst of it all,
civilian starships span the stars, maintaining an open threat against any new
       invasion and trying to make a few credits while they're at it.
You too have felt the lure of this; the desire for a unique freedom that most
citizens will never know, the drive to explore, the need to defend your species,
         and yes, greed for the vast wealth that is to be had.
                   It is time to take to the stars.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Welcome to the original and still the most innovative pulp science fiction
multiplayer roleplaying adventure!
Originally opened in its classic form on 19 December 1998! Reopened in its new
iteration on 28 February 2009!
All original work (including setting, non-player characters, design, source
code, all related background material, and all text) located in this game or on
the Squidsoft.net website is copyright (c) Squidsoft.net 1998-2015. Unauthorised
reproduction prohibited.
Warning: Speech in this game is largely uncensored, and sensitive individuals
may find some other players offensive. The staff is ultimately not responsible
for the words and actions of the players.
The last server reset was at Fri Jul 22 13:40:17 2016 UTC
We're on Twitter! @StarConquest for server status notifications and out-of-game
contact!

    * Welcome to Star Conquest! *
[Starship "William Dove"; Living Quarters One]
This is a small room designed to give crew members a place to sleep while on
long journeys, and it isn't large enough to do much else. A long counter is
bolted to the wall opposite the entryway, and two narrow bunks have been bolted
to the two remaining walls. A small keypad is next to the door, controlling a
simple lock. The status lights overhead are currently not receiving power.
Looking through the windows, you see that the ship is at Old Frontier Processor;
Docking Bay.
You see a glossy sapphire blue ceramic felo chow bowl, a small yellow ball
containing a realistic Bari horde noisemaker, a small seashell pink trash can, a
white four poster rattan bed with a heart-shaped headboard and filmy deep purple
hangings with a set of lavender silk sheets, a soft periwinkle cashmere blanket,
a large periwinkle bed pillow, a large periwinkle bed pillow, and a hand-made
purple and amethyst flower quilt on it, a large oval dark purple and light
purple cloth rug, and a small oval turquoise rattan table with a glass top here.
You can go out.
(You are lying on a white four poster rattan bed with a heart-shaped headboard
and filmy deep purple hangings with a set of lavender silk sheets, a soft
periwinkle cashmere blanket, a large periwinkle bed pillow, a large periwinkle
bed pillow, and a hand-made purple and amethyst flower quilt on it.)

yourself and you don't have a stun weapon.

l
[Old Frontier Processor; Docking Bay]
The hydraulics for the airlocks lining the long side of this spacious docking
bay run quietly and efficiently, transporting each newly docked ship to an
individual berth outlined with square white lights above and below. The nearly
seamless walls and floor are constructed of light gray metal with signs and
hatchways accented in dark green. Though few people are about, it seems a very
well built and maintained station.
The five-person A.S.S. tactical platform "William Dove" is landed here.
You see an automatic teller machine here.
You can go north, northeast, south, northwest, and up.

A voice comes over the speaker and says, "William Dove, you have clearance to
launch. Good luck and come back to us safely."
Lily Kaise presses a button and brings up the FTL flight control board.
Providence Station shines brightly in the dark, one of the few stations that
bothers to illuminate its outer hull. The gleaming hull of the station is bathed
with bright white floodlights.
New Earth rotates through space before you, a startingly verdant planet, colored
in greens and blues with pure white clouds.
Via general sector communication, New Earth transmits, "Hello there, William
Dove! Welcome to home space!"
Lily Kaise presses a button and brings up the starship's navigation controls.
A destination appears on the ship's navigation controls: New Earth.
You notice Lily Kaise using the radio to ask for landing clearance.
A voice comes over the speaker and says, "Hello, William Dove. We read your AEU
transponder. You are cleared to land at the city of New Phoenix."

white and sapphire star quilt on it.

ftl clarkson
The League's legendary shipyards hang motionless in the dark here. Once, the
stations would be all but glowing with waste heat as the Intersector
Shipbuilding Company rolled out ship after ship. Now the stations are still and
darkened, and the ISC is no more.

laugh
You laugh.
Lily Kaise says in a New Earth accent, "Woo."
gen 8
Lily Kaise stands up from your lap.
Via general sector communication, this ship transmits a standard signal: "Leave
the sector for your own safety."
Via general sector communication, Masturbation transmits a text-based
transmission: "You got it, chief."
A small comet breaks apart into pieces!
Lily Kaise laughs.
The computer reports that the two-person medium transport "Masturbation" has
jumped out of the sector.
yellow
You lift a small plastic cover and press a yellow button.
The computer reports that the three-person light escort "Armored Furry" has
jumped into the sector.
The computer reports that the one-person fighter "Rodgers" has jumped into the
sector.
The computer reports that the one-person fighter "WE ARE PIRATES, HONEST" has
jumped into the sector.
Lily Kaise glides up.
rjed
I don't understand that.
red
You lift a small plastic cover and press a red button.
A loud klaxon sounds and red lights flash overhead as the ship enters red alert.
You hear a low hum as the ship's weapons are powered up.

the ship enters normal status.

powered down.

A pair of odd-colored stars, one green and one blue, mark this curious area of
space. The sensors are picking up odd bits of noise that the ship's computer
insists on trying to convert to audio. Once in a while, something that could
almost sound like a word emerges from a burst of static.
The computer reports that in-sector beacons are transmitting the following:

trace
No recent FTL drive traces detected.
This area of space is within the green belt of the nearest star, but there are
no life-bearing planets here. Instead there is merely an odd cluster of space
stations of unknown origin.
Lily Kaise presses a button on the FTL drive tracer control board.
No recent FTL drive traces detected.
The sensor noise is much worse here, with a constant dark, gutteral snarling
sound emanating from the ship's speakers. It almost sounds like a language, but
it's nothing you've ever heard before, and the ship's computer cannot pinpoint a
source.
Lily Kaise presses a button on the FTL drive tracer control board.
No recent FTL drive traces detected.

[Starship "Striking Distance"; Weapons Room]
Unlike the control room, a starship's weapon room has only one tiny viewport.
The focus of the room is a slightly miniaturized starmap, augmented with
additional spatial relationship information and various status displays. A
streamlined control board sits before the starmap, with prominent indicators for
lock status and weapon readiness. Control boards for the ship's weaponry are off
to either side, to be pulled into place at a moment's notice. The status lights
overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the windows, you see
that the ship is in a garage.
You see a swiveling gray leather gunner's chair, an improved temporary wormhole
drive, and a bioaugmentation plant in a small pot labeled "Starseekers" here.
You can go south and down.

that the ship is in a garage.

[Starship "Starlight Express"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a felo nest, a glossy pearl gray ceramic felo chow bowl, Mekensie the
humanoid service robot, a sleeping hefty light red soldier felo, a sleeping
hefty white soldier felo, a big red soldier felo, and a hefty light red soldier
felo here.
You can go south and out.
s
[Starship "Starlight Express"; Main Deck]

a sleeping big red soldier felo, a big red soldier felo, and a big red soldier
felo kitten here.
You can go north, east, south, west, and up.

l violet
a hefty violet sabre-toothed felo
This strange, six-legged creature is vaguely cat-like, though its head appears
almost vulpine. It is large in size and covered in average-length, tabby violet
fur, possessing a short, crooked tail that slowly flicks back and forth. The
felo's long, thick legs each end in three-toed paws with average, curved brown
claws visible. A violet, diamond nose sits below a pair of bright blue eyes with
irregular pupils. A pair of vicious sabre-tooth fangs protrude from its mouth.

l lily
Lily Kaise
She appears to be 27 years old. She is about five feet and two inches tall and
has fair skin. Her body is thin with attractively curved hips and shapely
calves. She has slender shoulders and slightly larger than average breasts. Her
face is oval and pretty, with a delicate nose and understated chin. Her lips are
lovely and blush pink and occasionally part to reveal a set of pretty teeth.
Beneath a set of arched eyebrows, her eyes are blue-green and almond-shaped. Her
waist-length, straight hair is pale honey blonde and swept up into a thick fall
of loose curls down her back. She has oval pink fingernails.
A small enameled cerulean blue dragonfly pierces her left earlobe and a small
enameled cerulean blue dragonfly pierces her right earlobe.
 She is wearing a sleeveless buttercup yellow cotton top with a v-neck and a row
of tiny embroidered flowers at the edges, a pair of white low rise denim jeans,
and a pair of shiny buttercup yellow patent leather clogs. She is also wearing
an orange and white blessed prayer bracelet around her wrist, a slender bracelet
of tiny tinkling silver bells around her wrist, a neon purple wrist-mounted
chronometer, a solid silver ring engraved with dragonflies, a delicate ring of
silver wire and small purple amethyst crystals, a metallic gold touch einrophone
in a metallic purple reinforced plastic phone holster, and a soft fuchsia
Tardick lizard snuggly labeled 'Asteria'. Her head, face, both eyes, neck, both
elbows, both forearms, both wrists, both hands, and waist are left uncovered.
She is carrying a big red soldier felo kitten in her right hand, and a hefty
light red soldier felo in her left hand.
[General Communication] Melinda Michaels transmits, "How's it going?"
Lily Kaise asks in a New Earth accent, "Ok I got a kitten and a hefty one is
that ok?"

l last soldier
a big green soldier felo
This strange, six-legged creature is vaguely wolf-like, though its head appears
almost vulpine. It is large in size and covered in average-length, spotted green
fur, possessing a short, thin tail that slowly flicks back and forth. The felo's

bright indigo eyes with horizontal pupils.

an obese green soldier felo
This strange, six-legged creature is vaguely wolf-like, though its head appears
almost vulpine. It is large in size and covered in short, spotted green fur,
possessing a short, thin tail that slowly flicks back and forth. The felo's
long, thin legs each end in three-toed paws with thick, hooked yellow claws,
visible only when not retracted. A orange, vertical nose sits below a pair of
bright indigo eyes with horizontal pupils.

[Starship "Daisy May"; Engineering Room]
The engineering room is much cleaner and sterile than most people expect when
they first board a starship. Though there are some exposed, thick bundles of
wires running here and there, most of the actual workings of the ship are deeper
in its structure. Instead, the room is virtually bare and brightly lit, with one
wall dominated by a large graphical representation of the ship and its
components, alongside current estimates of damage levels. On the right is a
small starmap set into a wall, displaying a bare minimum of information so that
it is not a distraction to the one keeping the ship together. A simple control
board allows the operator to prioritize repairs. The status lights overhead are
currently not receiving power. Looking through the windows, you see that the
ship is in a garage.
You see a temporary wormhole drive and a crudely hammered scrap metal feeding
trough here.
You can go north and south.
n
You begin familiarizing yourself with the engineering stations and making
various changes to your liking.

An AEU Pilot's Guide To Ships And Upgrades                                      
  Page 18
Long-term rentals:
The fighter and heavy bomber listed in this section are generally similar to the
ones rented at Tannhauser, save for the fact that I'm pretty sure they start out
with stock upgrades and have to be upgraded by the long-term renter. The modular
tactical platform and the Modular Terrorerotici both can only have
corporation-based fighters such as the hyperion ships or the ones rented either
short-term or long-term by Agnar attached to them as far as we've deduced, as
well as the shuttles manufactured by corporations such as Hermes or United. You
can attach the ships to the platforms only from space. Note: the docking bay
size of the tactical platform and the Terrorerotici will increase depending on
the types of ships you have attached to them.
One-Person A.S.S. Fighter 2,000,000.00 (Helios Agnarr's Interstellar Siege Force
Long Term Rental)
ASS-A1 ALLIED STARSHIPS SPACE SUPERIORITY FIGHTER
Requirements: 0 industry points
Model number: ASS-A1                    Designation: A.S.S. Fighter
Turret hardpoints: 4                    Launcher hardpoints: 1
Standard storage capacity: 6500         Standard battery hours: 3
Docking bay size required: 5
Class Modifications:
Damage vs. Small Ships: 120%            Hull Hit Chance by Small Ships: 90%
Instantaneous Speed: 105%
One-Person A.S.S. Bomber 15,000,000.00 (Helios Agnarr's Interstellar Siege Force
Long Term Rental)
ASS-A2 ALLIED STARSHIPS HEAVY BOMBER
Requirements: 200 industry points       200 combat points
Model number: ASS-A2                    Designation: A.S.S. Bomber
Turret hardpoints: 2                    Launcher hardpoints: 2
Standard storage capacity: 9750         Standard battery hours: 6
Docking bay size required: 5
Class Modifications:
Damage vs. Small Ships: 120%            Hull Hit Chance by Small Ships: 90%
Instantaneous Speed: 105%
Three-Person A.S.S. Modular Terrorerotici 250,000,000.00 (Helios Agnarr's
Interstellar Siege Force Long Term Rental)
ASS-C4 ALLIED STARSHIPS BUDGET-CONSTRAINED MODULAR TERROREROTICISM VESSEL
Requirements: 750 industry points       750 combat points
Model number: ASS-C4                    Designation: A.S.S. Modular
Terroreroticist
Turret hardpoints: 0                    Launcher hardpoints: 0
Standard storage capacity: 10000        Standard battery hours: 6
Docking bay size required: 35
Class Modifications:
Damage vs. Small Ships: 105%            Hull Hit Chance by Small Ships: 95%
Max Cruising Speed: 102%
ASS-E7 ALLIED STARSHIPS MODULAR TACTICAL PLATFORM
Requirements: 1250 industry points      1250 combat points
Model number: ASS-E7                    Designation: A.S.S. Tactical Platform
Turret hardpoints: 0                    Launcher hardpoints: 0
Standard storage capacity: 20000        Standard battery hours: 2
Docking bay size required: 50
Class Modifications:
Six-Person A.S.S. Frigate (approval required) (Helios Agnarr's Interstellar
Siege Force Long Term Rental)
ASS-F1 ALLIED STARSHIPS DEFENSE FRIGATE
Requirements: 1000 industry points      1000 combat points
Model number: ASS-F1                    Designation: A.S.S. Frigate
Turret hardpoints: 12                   Launcher hardpoints: 4
Standard storage capacity: 32000        Standard battery hours: 8
Docking bay size required: 100          Docking bay capacity: 37.5
   Class Modifications:
Instantaneous Speed: 95%
If you want to own a six-person ship to do stuff in and don't quite qualify for
the Pincer, then this ship is for you! It has fewer weapons, but would be able
to perform well enough in a fight with decent upgrades. It does however require
you to fill out an application, and approval or denial notifications may take
some time to reach you, but you'll be notified by mail regardless.
Lily Kaise says in a New Earth accent, "Yeah I don't usually but it is actually
more efficient and I should."

post in General/General.

Subject: Re: station discussion
Author: Melinda Michaels
Posted: 23:33 23 August 2316 GST
--
Morris, just do 285 and 134. I know Orion will be lower as the grade is lower.
Ather, I agree with you, I don't want to see Orion dropped.
Lily, my thing is not man power to build. I just simply think it's not necessary
to maintain three salvage stations. For one thing, Orion and 285 are very close
together and Orion stays. Then 134 is over 13 light-years out, if folks get the
option of higher grade for just a few light-years out, they will most likely go
there and 134 begins to be put up for very little earnings.
We've got one local station, another that's 4.something light-years out and the
other is over 13.
Melinda

Subject: Re: station discussion
Author: Lily Kaise
Posted: 23:41 23 August 2316 GST
--
Well most people aren't willing to pay a toll to shuttle back and forth to Orion
for 285 or 134 but i agree with you, I'd support a Salvaging station in 285
moreso as it is much higher in grade. I haven't seen that much activity from the
Salvaging station in 134 but ironically, it's the one from which my organization
has earned the 3 command points it has. So I'd say that for newly founded
organizations, being able to participate on Salvage processing stations is very
helpful. We definitely need to maintain Orion for all of the aforementioned
points. Just let me know if there's anything i can assist with.
--

Lily Kaise asks in a New Earth accent, "Hmm I guess would be good to wait until

some asteroids and then come back to asteorid mine or if you have any other
ideas?"
Lily Kaise says in a New Earth accent, "Um asteroid."

Processing Nuclear Temporary Station from the two-person hardened asteroid

beats its claws together.

white and sapphire star quilt on it.

nap!"

tentacles tightly around a small plastic statue of a shark, then loses interest
and jets off.

skim accelerator network."

skim acceleration gates now."

left the sector via quantum skim.

The computer announces, "Three."
The computer announces, "Two."
The computer announces, "One."
The computer announces, "Skim subroutine initialized."
You feel the deck underneath you shudder violently, and you stumble slightly.

left the sector via quantum skim.
The shuddering finally settles down.
The computer announces, "Skim initialization complete."

What was once a feature of interstellar geography is now the name of an
alliance, and the heart of Fringe space can be found past this gateway. The tiny
station of Nuevo Laredo stands guard here.
The planet of Chetumal floats before you here, the richest planet among the
Fringe Worlds, although that isn't saying a lot.

[Accord of Free Worlds Command; Docking Bay Three]
This is a fully modern docking bay, made of the same sleek, slightly darkened
metal that the exterior of the station is made from. Brightly painted yellow
lines mark entry and exit paths for ships, and rows of dotted lines indicate
where ships may touch down. A series of electromagnetic manipulators prevent
atmosphere from escaping into space when the bay door is opened. A few of the
lines here are painted blue instead of yellow, and seem to be reserved for
emergency traffic. A ramp leads up to the rest of the station.
The two-person Accord space module scout "Help Us Small Modules", the
four-person Accord space module transport "Temp Station Condensation", the
four-person Accord space module transport "Segue", the four-person Accord space
module transport "Just Dropping In", and the five-person morningstar "Armonioso"
are landed here.
You can go southeast, southwest, and up.
se
You scramble to your feet.
[Starship "Armonioso"; Corridor]
You can go north, northeast, south, northwest, and up.
peer n
You peer north...
[Starship "Armonioso"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. Lights
overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows,
you see that the ship is at Accord of Free Worlds Command; Docking Bay Three.
You see a decoy beacon launcher here.
Soraya Rhyz and Keegan Wantz are standing here.
You can go south and out.
nw
[Starship "Armonioso"; Weapons Room One]
You can go southeast.

Keegan Wantz's voice comes over the loudspeaker and says, "Anyone not know how
to use the wasps?"
The starship transitions into another sector.

A single star shines brightly in the dark here, the light strangely comforting.
The ship's sensors indicate that the star's spectrum is nearly identical to
Sol's.
Hyperion's famous Sea of Grass is immediately obvious upon gazing at the planet,
the rolling, meters-deep expanse of tall grasses obscuring the contours of the
surface.

[Hyperion; New Road]
At the west end of this new asphalt road, seemingly plopped down in the middle
of the sea of grass just north of the wall surrounding Jacktown, is a modern
industrial complex of steel and white concrete. The main building is three
stories tall, constructed of sleek white concrete, and has long tinted windows
framed in gleaming steel across the front. Behind it are several large white
warehouse-like structures. The area in front is landscaped with young trees and
short vividly green grass. A sign beside the main entrance reads, 'Applied
Automation.'

ftl new
Providence Station shines brightly in the dark, one of the few stations that
bothers to illuminate its outer hull. The gleaming hull of the station is bathed
with bright white floodlights.
New Earth rotates through space before you, a startingly verdant planet, colored
in greens and blues with pure white clouds.
Via general sector communication, New Earth transmits, "Hello there, Kalina!
Welcome to home space!"

You peer up...
[New Earth; Spaceport Landing Pad]
The busy landing pad of New Earth's capital city's spaceport sits over a large
bay at the tip of the southern continent. The pad itself is a huge square sheet
of white plasteel surrounded by gleaming new starship service structures. On the
southern side of the pad is a circular structure with wide transparisteel
windows affording a fabulous view of the ocean. A softly lit sign over the
transparisteel doorway reads, 'Pilot Lounge,' and a separate doorway is marked
'Liaison Office.' It looks like you can GO into either of those places. To the
west, a bridge spans the gap between the landing pad and the rest of the
spaceport.
You see an automatic teller machine and a small trash can here.
You can go north, south, west, and down.
Akira Kazama glides in from above.
Akira Kazama opens an asteroid hauling supply kit.

exp
Among the AEU, you have a good amount of starship combat points, not very many
aggregate points, not very many exploration points, not very many industry
points, and relatively few ground combat points.
Related to industry, you are very good with asteroid hauls, inexperienced with
Teslatown activities, very inexperienced with salvages, very inexperienced with
deliveries, very inexperienced with belt management, very inexperienced with
asteroid mining, very inexperienced with passengers, very inexperienced with
atmospheric scooping, very inexperienced with salvage operations, and very
inexperienced with trading.
Related to starship combat, you are the best at combat gunning, good with
mission-related ship kills, inexperienced at combat piloting, very inexperienced
at advanced engineering techniques, very inexperienced with minor skirmish ship
kills, very inexperienced at defending salvage operations, and very
inexperienced with invading ship kills.
Related to ground combat, you are inexperienced with weapon hits, inexperienced
with kills, and very inexperienced with ground missions.
Related to exploration, you are inexperienced at the exploration of the
Glyphmaker ruins, inexperienced with local artifact finds, inexperienced with
alien artifact finds, very inexperienced with space imaging, very inexperienced
with planetary finds, and very inexperienced with assisted planetary finds.
Lily Kaise uses the ship's radio to ask flight control for launch clearance.
A voice comes over the speaker and says, "RockIt!, you have clearance to launch.
Good luck and come back to us safely."
l
[Starship "RockIt!"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. Lights
overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows,
you see that the ship is in space.
You see a small lavender trash bin, a large purple and lavender paisley floor
pillow with thick gold fringe, a large white and dusky pink paisley floor pillow
with thick silver fringe, a hairy yellow eight-legged ArachnoPal named Higgins,
a compact red refrigerator, and a small oval turquoise rattan table with a glass
top here.
Lily Kaise is sitting on a large purple and lavender paisley floor pillow.
You can go up and out.
(You are sitting on a large purple and lavender paisley floor pillow with thick
gold fringe.)
Lily Kaise presses a button and brings up the FTL flight control board.
wrap lily
You wrap your arms around Lily Kaise, pulling her close.
A pair of odd-colored stars, one green and one blue, mark this curious area of
space. The sensors are picking up odd bits of noise that the ship's computer
insists on trying to convert to audio. Once in a while, something that could
almost sound like a word emerges from a burst of static.
The computer reports that in-sector beacons are transmitting the following:
M0<X9fcq2'E/WG[au1;7X+Ka"l1;yL2I6@|k#YZI
Lily Kaise wraps her arms around you, pulling you close.
This area of space is within the green belt of the nearest star, but there are
no life-bearing planets here. Instead there is merely an odd cluster of space
stations of unknown origin.
The sensor noise is much worse here, with a constant dark, gutteral snarling
sound emanating from the ship's speakers. It almost sounds like a language, but
it's nothing you've ever heard before, and the ship's computer cannot pinpoint a
source.
Via general sector communication, Beacon E-02 transmits in a robotic voice,
"Detecting vessel 'RockIt!.' Welcome to The Belt of Orion."
Lily Kaise presses a button and brings up the FTL flight control board.
Lily Kaise transfers a toll payment to a local rift accelerator.
[Notification from Starseekers] The organization has received 1,908,002.34 EAOS
credits from a toll payment to League Rift Accelerating Solar Toll Station in
The Belt of Orion.
The computer announces, "Setting course to Asteroid Beacon Alpha 285. Local rift
accelerator with matching vector found."
Something deep inside the starship roars to life as the lights dim sharply.
A wormhole suddenly appears in front of the ship, its edges tinged an unusual
deep purple. Strange undulating shapes are half-visible deep inside it.
A thick undulating mist suddenly seems to rush toward the starship from every
direction, quickly blotting out the stars. Random shapes, some half-familiar,
occasionally form in the mist only to disappear almost immediately.
The formless mists suddenly resolve into a dust-laden wind. After a moment the
dust settles, and one of the horses in front of you lets out a quiet whicker as
the carriage's wheels creak ceaselessly below.
caress lily on back
You gently caress Lily Kaise's back.
A hairy yellow eight-legged ArachnoPal named Higgins taps his claws on the
floor.

l lily
Lily Kaise
She appears to be 27 years old. She is about five feet and two inches tall and
has fair skin. Her body is thin with attractively curved hips and shapely
calves. She has slender shoulders and slightly larger than average breasts. Her
face is oval and pretty, with a delicate nose and understated chin. Her lips are
lovely and blush pink and occasionally part to reveal a set of pretty teeth.
Beneath a set of arched eyebrows, her eyes are blue-green and almond-shaped. Her
waist-length, straight hair is pale honey blonde and swept up into a thick fall
of loose curls down her back. She has oval pink fingernails.
A small enameled cerulean blue dragonfly pierces her left earlobe and a small
enameled cerulean blue dragonfly pierces her right earlobe.
 She is wearing a sleeveless buttercup yellow cotton top with a v-neck and a row
of tiny embroidered flowers at the edges, a pair of white low rise denim jeans,
and a pair of shiny buttercup yellow patent leather clogs. She is also wearing
an orange and white blessed prayer bracelet around her wrist, a slender bracelet
of tiny tinkling silver bells around her wrist, a neon purple wrist-mounted
chronometer, a solid silver ring engraved with dragonflies, a delicate ring of
silver wire and small purple amethyst crystals, a metallic gold touch einrophone
in a metallic purple reinforced plastic phone holster, a soft fuchsia Tardick
lizard snuggly labeled 'Asteria', and a Tardick lizard named Asteria perched on
her shoulder. Her head, face, both eyes, neck, both elbows, both forearms, both
wrists, both hands, and waist are left uncovered.
She is carrying nothing.

at the asteroid's surface through the scope.

okay to fire. You pull the trigger and an anchor shoots rapidly from the barrel
of a bulky asteroid supply cannon! You lift off the asteroid's surface slightly,
landing as the anchor finishes securing itself.

at a single-use asteroid anchor through the scope.
(47 seconds roundtime.)

from the barrel to automatically secure itself to a single-use asteroid anchor
with an attached line.

[Starship "RockIt!"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. Lights
overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows,
you see that the ship is at Metal-rich Asteroid Surface.

You raise a bulky asteroid supply cannon to your eye and begin carefully aiming
at the asteroid's surface through the scope.
(11 seconds roundtime.)
After a few careful seconds aligning everything in the scope, it flashes the
okay to fire. You pull the trigger and an anchor shoots rapidly from the barrel
of a bulky asteroid supply cannon! You lift off the asteroid's surface slightly,
landing as the anchor finishes securing itself.
use cannon
You raise a bulky asteroid supply cannon to your eye and begin carefully aiming
at a single-use asteroid anchor through the scope.
(41 seconds roundtime.)
eta
Wait 7 seconds.
The scope flashes the okay to fire. You pull the trigger and more ribbon line
shoots out to automatically secure itself to a single-use asteroid anchor with
an attached line. It quickly spools itself up, tensioning tightly over your
ship. Hopefully it will hold.

The hiss of air slowly fades away into nothingness, and the yellow light becomes
red.

[Starship "RockIt!"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. Lights
overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows,
you see that the ship is at Metal-rich Asteroid Surface.
You see a small lavender trash bin, a large purple and lavender paisley floor

[Starship "RockIt!"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. Lights
overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows,
you see that the ship is in space.
You see a small lavender trash bin, a large purple and lavender paisley floor
pillow with thick gold fringe, a large white and dusky pink paisley floor pillow
with thick silver fringe, a compact red refrigerator, and a small oval turquoise
rattan table with a glass top here.
Lily Kaise is standing here.
You can go up and out.
(You are sitting on a large purple and lavender paisley floor pillow with thick
gold fringe.)

[General Communication] Lily Kaise transmits, "134 is still up."

l refrig
a compact red refrigerator
This compact red refrigerator is made tall and narrow to fit into the often
cramped spaces aboard a starship or space station. Because of its excellent
insulation, food and drink stored in it will not spoil.
It is open.
Inside it you see a day old serving of baked five-cheese ziti with Italian
sausage meatballs and tomato sauce, a day old serving of baked five-cheese ziti
with Italian sausage meatballs and tomato sauce, a day old green garden salad
drizzled with black peppercorn ranch dressing, a day old green garden salad
drizzled with black peppercorn ranch dressing, a slice of sausage and roasted
pepper pizza, a slice of sausage and roasted pepper pizza, a slice of sausage
and roasted pepper pizza, a slice of sausage and roasted pepper pizza, a slice
of three-meat pizza, a slice of three-meat pizza, a large spicy shredded beef
taco topped with shredded cheese, a slice of white chocolate cheesecake drizzled
with raspberry sauce, a slice of white chocolate cheesecake drizzled with
raspberry sauce, a single-serving mocha and chocolate layered tiramisu, a
single-serving mocha and chocolate layered tiramisu, a frosty mug full of root
beer, a frosty mug full of root beer, a frosty mug full of root beer, a frosty
mug full of root beer, a basket of cheese breadsticks, a basket of cheese
breadsticks, and a slice of pinwheel pizza.

your suit, you gradually begin to hear the hiss of air entering the airlock.
The hiss of air slowly fades away into nothingness, and the yellow light becomes
green.

a compact red refrigerator
This compact red refrigerator is made tall and narrow to fit into the often
cramped spaces aboard a starship or space station. Because of its excellent
insulation, food and drink stored in it will not spoil.

A handful of lonely beacons watch over this area of space, their lights glowing
palely in the dark, surrounded by tendrils of drifting dust and debris.
A planet once existed here, until it was destroyed by the Outsiders. Now only
large chunks of the planet remain, still drifting slowly away from each other,
with clouds of debris filling the sector.
A circular space station dominates this sector, made of darkened metal
reinforced against attack. By the look of it, this is probably the most heavily
armored station in human space, excepting The Torus. This is the heart of the
Accord of Free Worlds.
Lily Kaise presses a button and brings up the starship's navigation controls.

[1] Small Precharged Battery                                5,000,000.00 EAOS
credits / 1 megacredits
    This small battery array will not provide much power or keep your station
online for very long, but it is the best option for getting a station online on
the cheap.
    Power Supplied: 50
[2] Medium Precharged Battery                               15,000,000.00 EAOS
credits / 3 megacredits
    This medium-sized battery array provides below-average power levels, but it
does keep your station online for several days.
    Industry: 500
    Power Supplied: 75
[3] Standard Fusion Containment                             20,000,000.00 EAOS
credits / 4 megacredits
    This is the standard power source for small space stations. Its power level
is adequate for many needs and the station will remain online for several days.
    Industry: 1000
    Power Supplied: 100
[4] Large Precharged Battery                                40,000,000.00 EAOS
credits / 8 megacredits
    This large battery array manages to match the output of the fusion power
plant and lasts a bit longer.
    Industry: 1500
    Power Supplied: 100
[5] Solar Panel Array                                       30,000,000.00 EAOS
credits / 6 megacredits
    Solar power is a reliable and efficient way to power a space station. This
proven system's minimal strain will keep a station online for over a week. Of
course, it is only useful in the vicinity of a star.
    Industry: 2000  Exploration: 500
    Power Supplied: Variable -- 100 at Sol-equivalent luminosity
[6] Small Blast Chamber                                     30,000,000.00 EAOS
credits / 6 megacredits
    This is a debris-burning fusion blast chamber. It can provide a good amount
of power for a significant length of time. However, it must be kept supplied
with raw material. This model is much more energy efficient than its larger
cousin, but it also has a smaller furnace capacity due to its size.
    Industry: 2500  Exploration: 650
    Power Supplied: 125
[7] Fission Breeder Reactor                                 50,000,000.00 EAOS
credits / 10 megacredits
    This is a modular fission power plant. It will give a space station a great
deal of power, though not the longest lifetime.
    Industry: 3000  Exploration: 500
    Power Supplied: 150
[8] Blast Chamber                                           50,000,000.00 EAOS
credits / 10 megacredits
    This is a debris-burning fusion blast chamber. It can provide a great deal
of power for a significant length of time. However, it must be kept supplied
with raw material.
    Industry: 4000  Exploration: 750
    Power Supplied: 175
[9] Slow-burning Fusion Containment                         120,000,000.00 EAOS
credits / 24 megacredits
    This is an extremely long-lasting power source suitable for small stations.
    Industry: 7500
    Power Supplied: 30

l
[Starship "RockIt!"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is at Accord of Free Worlds Command; Docking Bay
Four.
You see a small lavender trash bin, a large purple and lavender paisley floor
pillow with thick gold fringe, a large white and dusky pink paisley floor pillow
with thick silver fringe, a compact red refrigerator, and a small oval turquoise
rattan table with a glass top here.
Lily Kaise is sitting on a large purple and lavender paisley floor pillow.
You can go up and out.

[Asteroid Belt Management Station]
This is an asteroid belt management station. Through large transparisteel
windows, you can see the asteroid stations themselves glittering amongst the
tumbling asteroids of the belt. The station managers need never actually visit
these stations, however, instead conducting their business via a number of
terminals.

in the belt of Orion. There is also one by going west of b-24 to 135 and then
traveling to 134."
[General Communication] Demarco Scott transmits, "There isn't a station that
goes to the debris area?"
[General Communication] Morris Corlew transmits, "Which debris area?"
[General Communication] Sakura Arakida transmits, "There's been only the orion
station for getting normal debris like commets. But there's no station in what
used to be that old, ort cloud, full of commets and other stuff up to grade 50
for, not sure how long. People use 134, or grapple roids. Personally I'm not
fond of either but that's just me. I find comets to be balanced, but grade 30
leaves much to be desired."
[General Communication] Morris Corlew transmits, "If you're talking about 285,
there is currently nothing accepting debris there. Just the roid station. If you
salvage out at 285, you have to come back to 286 and drop at Orion."
[General Communication] Demarco Scott transmits, "Ah, I see."

l
[Starship "William Dove"; Living Quarters One]
This is a small room designed to give crew members a place to sleep while on
long journeys, and it isn't large enough to do much else. A long counter is
bolted to the wall opposite the entryway, and two narrow bunks have been bolted
to the two remaining walls. A small keypad is next to the door, controlling a
simple lock. The status lights overhead are currently not receiving power.
Looking through the windows, you see that the ship is at New Earth; Spaceport
Landing Pad.
You see a glossy sapphire blue ceramic felo chow bowl, a small yellow ball
containing a realistic Bari horde noisemaker, a small seashell pink trash can, a
white four poster rattan bed with a heart-shaped headboard and filmy deep purple
hangings with a set of lavender silk sheets, a soft periwinkle cashmere blanket,
a large periwinkle bed pillow, a large periwinkle bed pillow, and a hand-made
purple and amethyst flower quilt on it, a large oval dark purple and light
purple cloth rug, a small oval turquoise rattan table with a glass top, and a
Tardick lizard named Asteria here.
Lily Kaise is lying on a white four poster rattan bed.
You can go out.
(You are lying on a white four poster rattan bed with a heart-shaped headboard
and filmy deep purple hangings with a set of lavender silk sheets, a soft
periwinkle cashmere blanket, a large periwinkle bed pillow, a large periwinkle
bed pillow, and a hand-made purple and amethyst flower quilt on it.)

Subject: Re: station discussion
Author: Akemi Bando

We did without 134 for quite awhile. It's nice to have, but if we're going to
shuffle stations around I say let it go this time and put up a marker beacon in
the Battle of Mir, so that local artifact hunters are less likely to get lost. A
marker beacon on a large battery will last an outrageous amount of time, over a
month at least, and can be autotraveled to by ships without rift drives so long
as they're within 10 sectors of it.

FTL Interalliance Communications Network

Subject: Re: station discussion
Author: Kim Saunders
Posted: 08:11 24 August 2316 GST
--
Hi all,
We have some good discussion going on here.
I will try to comment on a few things i have read, others I will leave until I
have been able to do a bit more comparison.
1. Yes, the salvage processor and xenology in Belt of Orion should stay there,
for the reasons several people have already given.
2. salvaging in 134 can give very few or very many industry points, depending on
how patient you are. But then again, if you did 5 loads with more larger pieces
of debris, you might maybe get similar results and spend the same time some
people spend collecting only the tiny pieces of debris and leaving the hunks of
metal, control boards and sensor components. I am personally way past the point
where 134 is of use to me, but I know that for new pilots earning those first
1000 industry points is the hardest, after that mighty grapple II and medium
transport, life does get easier.
3. 285 does offer pretty reasonable salvaging if you expel the lead and iron.
But I have found that 136 does offer grade 40 and sometimes 50 comets, and they
are nice to salvage too. I have not had the time to compare both places
thoroughly, but wil do so over the next few days.
4. As for asteroids, I really like the result at 285 a lot more. They pay on
average the same, but finding more closer together does allow you to get more
work done in a shorter space of time. The result is more money and more points,
for pilots and orgs. And the travel distance between one and the other is not
really that massive.
5. I think autotravel with autovector works at least 20 or 25 sectors out from a
beacon, or so it did when I last was that far out. That's neither here nor there
though. Both battle of mir and 134 give you lots of artifacts on some days, and
very few on others. I have done only a bit of comparing, but for local artifacts
battle of mir is an option.
6. I think it is very hard to tell where your command points come from. I
believe that they, like other points, are not given out as whole points but as
tenth of a point, so you may not get to see them until you have earned a full
point.
This is it for me for this moment. Keep your experiences coming, so that we can
come up with a decision that we can all live with.
Kim
--

[2] Previous
[3] Return

FTL Interalliance Communications Network
--
Subject: Re: station discussion
Author: Morris Corlew
Posted: 13:11 24 August 2316 GST
--
The results are in. 
I used a medium transport with League Freighter-Class Storage Extender and a
double storage plant, giving it a total storage capacity of 120770, which is
201%  of standard storage. I also used a storage compressor. Grapple used was a
Mighty II. I did not expell anything from these loads prior to transferring. A
couple things; The debris out at Orion, as we know, is grade 20-30 in the form
of smallish asteroids, comets, etc. and generally about 2-5 meters in length.
The debris out at 285 is grade 40-60 in the form of slightly larger asteroids
and comets than Orion, and tend to be around 4 meters in length. 134 is
primarily small to medium shipwrecks with a grade of 20-30. The load I did out
there was a little odd in that it only contained small shipwrecks. You'll notice
there is a difference in the amount of pieces dropped at 134 compared to the
other two places. This may well have to do something with the point payout, but
like I said, I never expelled anything. Below are the results. Underneath that,
a few more thoughts and conclusions.
Orion dropped at Orion
Total Load: 120582
Load empty: 188
Total pieces: 67
SS received (credits only): 607,755.87
Payout (credits): 2,429,852.57
Payout (points): 11.5
Pieces donated to furnace: 1
285 dropped at Orion
Total Load: 120478
Load empty: 292
Total pieces: 62
SS received (credits only): 544,623.55
Payout (credits): 2,177,444.92
Payout (points): 13.7
Pieces donated to furnace: 1
134 dropped at 134
Total Load: 119860
Load empty: 910
Total pieces: 188
SS received (credits only): 674,489.29
Payout (credits): 2,696,657.65
Payout (points): 32.3
Pieces donated to furnace: N/A
Conclusion: Even though the grade at 285 is significantly higher than at Orion,
the payout in points is only slightly higher, and the cash payout both for
myself and for the org is actually higher at Orion. 134 has a much more
significant point payout and a slightly higher cash payout both for the org and
for myself. For any necessary comparison, because I have heard some of the
payout on some things is based on your level of industry points, so I will say
that I am currently close to 1300.
Thanks to Michael Winters for taking me out to get a roid so that I could pay
the toll out to 285! Hopefully this is helpful information in determining which
of these stations is useful for what.
--

[2] Previous

FTL Interalliance Communications Network
--
Subject: Re: station discussion
Author: Lily Kaise
Posted: 13:33 24 August 2316 GST
--
Here are a few more observations --
Shule and I hauled 20 asteroids earlier this morning from Alpha 285. I earned
463 million credits with an average payout of 23.15 million credits per
asteroid. Total Industry points earned by me were 40. Shule earned a total of
449 million credits with an average of 22.45 million credits per asteroid. We
earn on average more as our respective Industry is higher than 5000 Industry.
When I salvaged 3 loads of Grade 30 shipwrecks from 134, I only eliminated steel
but kept control boards and sensor components. The hold of my medium transport
is 105,720 with a storage plant. Each load was within plus or minus 1,000 units
of storage. Total points for all three loads were 76 and of course when divided
by 3 for the average yields 25.33 (rounded down). This is a very good points
average for grade 30 debris.
If 136 is located similarly to where there has been established a similar
arrangement without an Asteroid processor in prior months, when I have salvaged
in the area where 136 is, grade 50 comets were sparse and consisted primarily of
small comets with medium grade 50 comets being rare. No grade 60 asteroids were
present whereas grade 60 asteroids are more consistent than grade 50 comets.
Ideally, if we could have a debris field which yielded higher grade shipwrecks
or more frequent grade 50 comets in communications range, this would be optimal.
However to set up another operation for salvaging really isn't practical so I
would accept that the grade 40 to 60 asteroids in Alpha 285 would continue to be
a good compromise for higher grade debris along with decent asteroids to haul.
Battle of Mir artifacts are not as common as with 134 but I know that pilots who
have more experience than I remember that prior to the ability to build
temporary space stations, that one had to rift to an area such as 134 without
any of the current recharging or other supports and especially a relatively
short trek back to known beacons. I still would support 134 as an a better
alternative to Battle of Mir. I rarely hunt for Local artivacts anymore but just
as the Bubble is more accessible for those who are qualified for a Rift Drive, I
consider that an area such as 134 is just as viable for those who are working
towards their first Rift Drives.
--

Subject: Re: station discussion
Author: Akemi Bando
Posted: 14:02 24 August 2316 GST
--
I thought about it a little more, and having a closer option may outweigh the
benefit of having slightly better returns at 134. We've had chronic problems
with people going out to 134 and dozing off when the trip turns out to take more
than a few minutes owing to the distance from B-24 to 134 and the natural
variation in local rift conditions. I know several ships have been lost to
pirates looking to take advantage of inattentive pilots.
--

FTL Interalliance Communications Network

Subject: Re: station discussion
Author: Morris Corlew
Posted: 14:11 24 August 2316 GST
--
Well, considering I didn't expell anything, and I noticed that there would have
been a lot to expel out at 285, it might be that the payout there if you're
expelling is much more worth it. I'll wait on the next round of tests Melinda is
setting up. The only thing is, expelling means it does take considerably longer,
and I don't know that the gain in points (and I don't know if there is one with
cash payouts or not) equates to the extra time spent. This next round of tests
will be valuable to determine some of that. If it turns out that expelling makes
it equivalent to 134, then I would support putting both a salvage station and a
roid station in the same place that's closer. The lack of artifacts might be an
issue for some, it's not something I've focused on, so can't comment on that
other than that people have mentioned they are more sparse at Mir than at 134. I
did notice something at 285, and that's that you have to cover more sectors in
general to get a full load, based not only on the size of the debris chunks
compared to 134, but also that they are less prevalent; maybe two per sector as
oppoosed to four to six. I don't know how much that makes a difference for
different types of salvagers...those with more advanced equipment, including
faster engine speed, autovector, etc versus those without those things. The one
concern I have is that people who cannot get a Mighty II that can handle the
40-60 at 285 wouldn't want to or wouldn't know that they can use a different
grapple with a higher grade capability but lower strength.
--

Subject: Re: station discussion
Author: Sakura Arakida
Posted: 14:18 24 August 2316 GST
--
I'm just going to state my few thoughts. and what I'd like to see.
gaining, 30 points, for 188 pieces of debris, may look nice, but look at how
many pieces. from 134. take the same 188 pieces, and make that with grade 40 to
60 roids, expelling led and iron, it may take you several loads, but you could
in theory get, 50 or 60 points.
I personally find grappling shipwrecks to be long and tedious. when you expel
the larger stuff, I have salvaged for an hour straight, and got 200 pieces. and
only filled up 20k of my 120k medium transport. so to fill that up would take an
exceedingly long time. and for how much gain, yes those 200 pieces gave me
roughly 30 points, but is it worth it in the long run?
personally I'd like to see orion stay for the reasons listed. 134 and battle of
mir be used as artifacting spots, not, salvaging spots. 286, be used for roid
hauling, and we find, a cloud that has grade 30 to 50 or there abouts debris. be
it roids and comets. that seems to be pretty more balanced in my opinion. since
when salvaging roids, you're still expelling stuff so what's the most efficient
way to salvage. for me I prefer comets. small or medium matters not, they're
just the most balanced salvage as far as points verses credits verses time.
but these are just my thoughts.
so you wouldn't have to keep anything up in 134 but a beacon to travel between
there and 135,
286, keeps the roid station and beacon station,
orion keeps the salvage xeno, and what ever else.
if a balanced debris cloud was found, then, I could see a salvage station there,
and maybe an op station as well. but again these are my thoughts and what I'd be
more likely to use
if a balanced debris cloud was found, then, I could see a salvage station there,
and maybe an op station as well. but again these are my thoughts and what I'd be
more likely to use

all you need is the inserter and the beacon. keep 285 for roids so all you need
is beacon, inserter and roid station. orion for most salvage related things.
I am suggesting we find a new place to salvage, that's got a mix of comets and
roids, something like grade 30 to 50. since that's better balanced.
if that's done, you only need to keep up 2 salvage stations, instead of the
current 3.
but that's my 2 credits worth of an opinion.
personally I'm not fond of the salvage in 134, or, 285. though I did use 134 for
artifacts. when I wasn't having luck in battle of mir.
--

kiss lily

Lily Kaise laughs.
Lily Kaise kisses you.
chuckle

-lily Hi beautiful.
You say to Lily, "Hi beautiful."
Lily Kaise says in a New Earth accent, "I didn't include the bubble and GMG."
nod

Lily Kaise says in a New Earth accent, "I counted Orion as one of the 4 areas."
'Right.
You say, "Right."

Subject: Re: station discussion
Author: Sakura Arakida
Posted: 16:35 24 August 2316 GST
--
so the issue isn't maintaining 3 processers, it's just maintaining, too many
areas? then drop 134 and let all the new pilots deal with battle of mir.
I was under the impression that it was more, dealing with 3 salvage places.
285 may be good, but there's only 2 chunks per sector, and only asteroids. I was
taught that comets are the best points and credit wise. maybe not the most
expensive, but they are well balanced. that's why I was asking about a different
salvage spot.
but at least where salvaging's concerned. it's time invested, verses reward. and
making afficient use of one's time. make a prophet, while not spending 8 hours
trying to make it. take 134 if you salvage there, expell all the big stuff, it
will take a very long time to fill up, 108k. I got 200 pieces in a few hours.
and had only filled up a fifth of that. so to fill that all up. will be 10 hours
roughly. yes the points would be something like 90, but the time invested is
just a bit crazy.
grappeling strictly roids you could probably make that 90 points in a few loads,
still expelling led and iron. but it would take long to travel from point a to
point b.
if we had a place with 30 to 50 comets. as well as roids you have a good balance
there. with maybe 4 or 5 chunks per sector. like orion is now, but just a bit
further out to get better grade.
if we had a place with 30 to 50 comets. as well as roids you have a good balance
there. with maybe 4 or 5 chunks per sector. like orion is now, but just a bit
further out to get better grade.

Subject: Re: station discussion
Author: Morris Corlew
Posted: 16:48 24 August 2316 GST
--
Sakura, considering the times you've quoted, it's making me wonder if expelling
is even worth it. It seriously increases your amount of time spent. I could make
90 points in about 3 hours without expelling, why would I spend 10 hours
expelling the big pieces for the same reward? If I do 4 loads with a compressor
in 134, it takes about 3 hours if I work straight through and I average about
80-90 points. That makes a lot more sense to me than expelling stuff to get a
single load that gets me 90 points. I will have to try the expelling method
though to see what I think of it other than what you're describing here. I
actually just found out about it this morning, so have never done it that way.
--

Lily Kaise says in a New Earth accent, "What the."
[General Communication] Morris Corlew transmits, "No idea."
'wow!
You exclaim, "Wow!"
[General Communication] Demarco Scott transmits, "No clue."
Lily Kaise asks in a New Earth accent, "A robot full of felo corpses?"
A Tardick lizard named Asteria flicks its tongue out.
Lily Kaise strokes a Tardick lizard named Asteria's warm scaly skin.
[General Communication] Sakura Arakida transmits, "Oh my god. Who owns
that...they need to be smacked."
[General Communication] Melinda Michaels transmits, "What?"
'I think that's Cesar's?

[General Communication] Demarco Scott transmits, "Sure do."

[General Communication] Melinda Michaels transmits, "Oh my."
Jewel the large violet glowing felo wanders in from the north.
[General Communication] Demarco Scott transmits, "Hmm?"
[General Communication] Melinda Michaels transmits, "The news item."
[General Communication] Demarco Scott transmits, "I know."
A Tardick lizard named Asteria trundles slowly out.
squeeze lily
You squeeze Lily Kaise affectionately.

realistic Bari horde noisemaker.

Lily Kaise stretches.
Lily Kaise cuddles up to you.
cuddle lily

wrap lily
You wrap your arms around Lily Kaise, pulling her close.
Lily Kaise wraps her arms around you, pulling you close.
kiss lily on lips
You kiss Lily Kaise on the lips.
Lily Kaise kisses you on the lips.

[Starship "William Dove"; Living Quarters One]
This is a small room designed to give crew members a place to sleep while on
long journeys, and it isn't large enough to do much else. A long counter is
bolted to the wall opposite the entryway, and two narrow bunks have been bolted
to the two remaining walls. A small keypad is next to the door, controlling a
simple lock. The status lights overhead are currently not receiving power.
Looking through the windows, you see that the ship is at New Earth; Spaceport
Landing Pad.

containing a realistic Bari horde noisemaker, a small seashell pink trash can, a

hangings with a set of lavender silk sheets, a soft periwinkle cashmere blanket,
a large periwinkle bed pillow, a large periwinkle bed pillow, and a hand-made
purple and amethyst flower quilt on it, a large oval dark purple and light

sit chair
You sit down on a black leather captain's chair.
A single star shines brightly in the dark here, the light strangely comforting.
The ship's sensors indicate that the star's spectrum is nearly identical to
Sol's.
Hyperion's famous Sea of Grass is immediately obvious upon gazing at the planet,
the rolling, meters-deep expanse of tall grasses obscuring the contours of the
surface.
Via general sector communication, Hyperion transmits, "Hello there, Kalina!
Welcome to home space!"

FTL Interalliance Communications Network

Subject: Re: station discussion
Author: Morris Corlew
Posted: 18:42 24 August 2316 GST
--
Ok, so I came out here to 136 with a Fringeling cadet to introduce him to roid
hauling and also to do a little checking things out. The debris out here is
grade 30-50 asteroids and comets...basically the kind of place Sakura was
talking about. Yeah, the roids are less plentiful...way less plentiful. But they
are here. So, if we did want to do a combined spot, this might be a better
option than 285, depending on whether we wanted to focus more on the salvage or
on the roids. Not a recommendation or anything, it's just that Sakura got me
thinking about it.
--

l
[Endymion; Repair & Rearm; GalKit, Inc.]
A small office, its dimensions defined by temporary fiberboard partitions, has
been set up here between the front room of the repair and rearm facility and the
rest of the warehouse. A short, make-shift counter sits near the doorway with
several sheets of laminated technical specifications duct-taped to its surface.
The office's only decoration is a wrinkled poster on one of the fiberboard
walls. Technicians occasionally shuffle through the area, always making sure to
secure the inner door leading to the warehouse, so you can't see what is going
on back there.
You can go out.
l
[Endymion; Repair & Rearm; GalKit, Inc.]
A small office, its dimensions defined by temporary fiberboard partitions, has
been set up here between the front room of the repair and rearm facility and the
rest of the warehouse. A short, make-shift counter sits near the doorway with
several sheets of laminated technical specifications duct-taped to its surface.
The office's only decoration is a wrinkled poster on one of the fiberboard
walls. Technicians occasionally shuffle through the area, always making sure to
secure the inner door leading to the warehouse, so you can't see what is going
on back there.

[Starship "Kalina"; Control Room]
You see a tiger stripe leather sofa, a soft rectangular white rug with a design
of black and cinnamon brown cats, and a black leather captain's chair here.
You can go south and out.
power
You grasp a large lever on the control board and push it slowly away from you.
Status lights blink on all around you as faint hums and beeps begin to emanate
from the various starship systems.
launch
You use the ship's radio to ask flight control for launch clearance.
A voice comes over the speaker and says, "Kalina, you have clearance to launch.
Good luck and come back to us safely."

Providence Station shines brightly in the dark, one of the few stations that
bothers to illuminate its outer hull. The gleaming hull of the station is bathed
with bright white floodlights.

in greens and blues with pure white clouds.

ftl tesla
The sensors tell you that this area is full of valuable salvage, but all you can
see of it yourself is dark smudges that block the light of the stars.
The planet known as Teslaworld rotates below you, the atmosphere looking as
impenetrable as that of a gas giant. The thick clouds roil with continual
storms, and lightning flashes all across the sky many times a second.

[Teslatown; Finial Avenue] (inside a battlesuit)
Finial Avenue is a length of rather scorched concrete lined by the series of
tall lightning rods that gives it its name. An arching metal lattice overhead
and to either side forms a Faraday cage that keeps out electrical energy.
Scientists and technicians walk up and down the street, wearing environmental
suits which also act as Faraday cages in addition to possessing bulky cooling
units. Among these people occasionally stride even larger figures: people in
powered armor, their suits designed both for environmental protection and
intense ground combat.
You can go north and south.
n
You move north.

l
[Teslatown; Faraday Plaza] (inside a battlesuit)
Faraday Plaza is so named for the immense spherical Faraday cage that stretches
over its entirety, by far the largest such construct on the planet. The massive
cage encloses Teleforce Tom's Lounge and Pub as well as the Electrostatic
Exchange. A tall kiosk displaying mission postings stands in the very center of
the plaza.
You can go north, east, south, and west.

n
You press a button on a League Templar, which splits open down the front. You

[Teslatown; Finial Avenue] (inside a battlesuit)
Finial Avenue is a length of rather scorched concrete lined by the series of
tall lightning rods that gives it its name. An arching metal lattice overhead
and to either side forms a Faraday cage that keeps out electrical energy.
Scientists and technicians walk up and down the street, wearing environmental
suits which also act as Faraday cages in addition to possessing bulky cooling
units. Among these people occasionally stride even larger figures: people in
powered armor, their suits designed both for environmental protection and
intense ground combat.
You can go north and south.

You move north.

[Site 135486613; Surface] (inside a battlesuit)
You stand on the surface of Teslaworld. The levels of radiation and magnetic
flux here play havoc with your battlesuit's electronics, obscuring all input in
shifting levels of white noise. The sky is obscured by dark purple clouds, which
flash several times a second with bolts of lightning. Markings on the ground
show that this area has already been explored.
You can go down.

[Site 135486613; Entry Tunnel] (inside a battlesuit)
You stand at the entrance to a subterranean tunnel. The radiation level is
somewhat reduced here. Deeper in the tunnel, you can expect to find mineral
deposits and perhaps one or two alien artifacts, from whichever species occupied
this world before humanity established a presence. Markings on the ground show
that this area has already been explored.

[Site 118612912; Surface] (inside a battlesuit)
You stand on the surface of Teslaworld. The levels of radiation and magnetic
flux here play havoc with your battlesuit's electronics, obscuring all input in
shifting levels of white noise. The sky is obscured by dark purple clouds, which
flash several times a second with bolts of lightning. Markings on the ground
show that this area has already been explored.
You can go down.

heat.

[Site 182777756; Surface] (inside a battlesuit)
You stand on the surface of Teslaworld. The levels of radiation and magnetic
flux here play havoc with your battlesuit's electronics, obscuring all input in
shifting levels of white noise. The sky is obscured by dark purple clouds, which
flash several times a second with bolts of lightning. Markings on the ground
show that this area has already been explored.
You can go down.

flux here play havoc with your battlesuit's electronics, obscuring all input in

show that this area has already been explored.

level increases quickly as the tunnels wind into the depths of the planet.
Markings on the ground show that this area has already been explored.
You see the wreckage of Poacher Drone Alpha here.
You can go southwest and up.

[Teslatown; Faraday Plaza] (inside a battlesuit)
Faraday Plaza is so named for the immense spherical Faraday cage that stretches
over its entirety, by far the largest such construct on the planet. The massive
cage encloses Teleforce Tom's Lounge and Pub as well as the Electrostatic
Exchange.

[Starship "William Dove"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a sleek metal quantum entanglement communication device, a rattan floor
lamp with a light purple lotus shade (casting a white-colored glow), a wormhole
drive tracer, a dark purple leather captain's chair, a large oval white and
black cloth rug, a rare black EAOSian contoured couch with a hand-made white and
sapphire star quilt on it, a glossy purple ceramic felo chow bowl, a wall-sized
bubbling neon purple-lit aquarium containing yellow and violet aquatic life and
coral rocks, a small yellow ball containing a realistic Bari horde noisemaker, a
small white trash bin, a purple photocopier, a round white rattan coffee table
with a glass top, Purr the humanoid service robot, Bert the old hefty blue
soldier felo, and Jewel the large violet glowing felo here.
Lily Kaise is sleeping on a rare black EAOSian contoured couch.
You can go south and out.
(You are sitting on a rare black EAOSian contoured couch with a hand-made white
and sapphire star quilt on it.)

[Starship "William Dove"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a sleek metal quantum entanglement communication device, a rattan floor
lamp with a light purple lotus shade (casting a white-colored glow), a wormhole
drive tracer, a dark purple leather captain's chair, a large oval white and
black cloth rug, a rare black EAOSian contoured couch with a hand-made white and
sapphire star quilt on it, a glossy purple ceramic felo chow bowl, a wall-sized
bubbling neon purple-lit aquarium containing yellow and violet aquatic life and
coral rocks, a small yellow ball containing a realistic Bari horde noisemaker, a
small white trash bin, a purple photocopier, a round white rattan coffee table
with a glass top, Purr the humanoid service robot, and Jewel the large violet
glowing felo here.
Lily Kaise is sleeping on a rare black EAOSian contoured couch.
You can go south and out.
(You are sitting on a rare black EAOSian contoured couch with a hand-made white
and sapphire star quilt on it.)

You jet close to the hull of the four-person light carrier "Kalina" and begin
cycling the airlock.
A small light on the airlock control panel of Kalina turns from green to yellow.
A small light on the airlock control panel of Kalina turns from yellow to red.
You are now able to proceed inside.
[Starship "Kalina"; Airlock]
You can go enter into the ship.
You float close to the four-person light carrier "Kalina", open the hatch, and
carefully float inside, orienting yourself so that your feet hit the floor as
you enter the ship's artificial gravity field.
cycle
You press a large button marked CYCLE.
A small light on the airlock control panel turns from red to yellow. Through
your suit, you gradually begin to hear the hiss of air entering the airlock.
enter
You may not leave the airlock while it is cycling.
The hiss of air slowly fades away into nothingness, and the yellow light becomes
green.
enter
[Starship "Kalina"; Control Room]
You see a tiger stripe leather sofa, a soft rectangular white rug with a design
of black and cinnamon brown cats, and a black leather captain's chair here.
You can go south and out.

here.

from the various starship systems.
launch

1
The five-person A.S.S. tactical platform "Blanche Schroeder" has a compatible
base block system that allows the two ships to combine together to form a more
powerful vessel! You can request access to one of the base block docking rings,
or dock in the usual manner by connecting to the docking ring near the control
room.

process.
