changelog
Recent Minor Changes:
-----
Attempting to make payments on an insurance policy that does not exist now does
nothing. Previously it would break so this is probably an improvement.
   Posted 6 days, 7 hours, and 10 minutes ago
-----
ArachnoPals will no longer eat in their sleep, and their descriptions will now
indicate if they're hungry or sleeping.
   Posted 5 days, 22 hours, 12 minutes, and 42 seconds ago
-----
Added the option 'Show Less Salvage Grappling Output' under general options.
   Posted 5 days, 53 minutes, and 9 seconds ago
-----
Asteroid supply kits, along with individual anchors and lines, have been removed
from stores. A new weapon has been added in their place that significantly
reduces bloat.
   Posted 2 days and 13 seconds ago
-----
Fans of tombs rejoice! Enclosed spaces filled with death are stinkier than ever.
Such smells can be reversed with air freshener or engaging environmental
controls.
   Posted 35 minutes and 57 seconds ago
-----
l
[Starship "Blanche Schroeder"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You can go south and out.
(You are sitting.)

ftl drydock
A lone outpost glitters in an otherwise nondescript cloud of debris.
The League's legendary shipyards hang motionless in the dark here. Once, the
stations would be all but glowing with waste heat as the Intersector
Shipbuilding Company rolled out ship after ship. Now the stations are still and
darkened, and the ISC is no more.
move

battlecruiser-class starship.

Schroeder! Welcome to The Torus!"

out
[Starship "Blanche Schroeder"; Airlock]
You can go out and enter into the ship.
cycle
You press a large button marked CYCLE.
cycle
Indicators on the airlock door show that it is already cycling.
cycle
Indicators on the airlock door show that it is already cycling.
The computer announces, "Beginning cycling."
A small light on the airlock control panel turns from green to yellow. Through
your suit, you hear the hiss of air quickly leaving the airlock.
cancel
You are not currently in the assist queue.
The computer sounds a notification indicating that the ship has been fully
charged.
cancel
You are not currently in the assist queue.
cycle
Indicators on the airlock door show that it is already cycling.
The hiss of air slowly fades away into nothingness, and the yellow light becomes
red.
cycle
You press a large button marked CYCLE.
A small light on the airlock control panel turns from red to yellow. Through
your suit, you gradually begin to hear the hiss of air entering the airlock.
The hiss of air slowly fades away into nothingness, and the yellow light becomes
green.
The computer announces, "Cycling complete."
out
You exit the ship.

Providence Station shines brightly in the dark, one of the few stations that
bothers to illuminate its outer hull. The gleaming hull of the station is bathed
with bright white floodlights.
New Earth rotates through space before you, a startingly verdant planet, colored
in greens and blues with pure white clouds.

l lily
Lily Kaise
She appears to be 27 years old. She is about five feet and two inches tall and
has fair skin. Her body is thin with attractively curved hips and shapely
calves. She has slender shoulders and slightly larger than average breasts. Her
face is oval and pretty, with a delicate nose and understated chin. Her lips are
lovely and blush pink and occasionally part to reveal a set of pretty teeth.
Beneath a set of arched eyebrows, her eyes are blue-green and almond-shaped. Her
waist-length, straight hair is pale honey blonde and swept up into a thick fall
of loose curls down her back. She has oval pink fingernails.
A small enameled cerulean blue dragonfly pierces her left earlobe and a small
enameled cerulean blue dragonfly pierces her right earlobe.
 She is wearing a stretchy long-sleeved light blue top with a colorful dragonfly
print, a pair of skinny faded blue low rise jeans, and a pair of baby blue
leather clogs with a row of multicolored daisies across the toes. She is also
wearing an orange and white blessed prayer bracelet around her wrist, a slender
bracelet of tiny tinkling silver bells around her wrist, a neon purple
wrist-mounted chronometer, a solid silver ring engraved with dragonflies, a
delicate ring of silver wire and small purple amethyst crystals, a metallic gold
touch einrophone in a metallic purple reinforced plastic phone holster, and a
soft fuchsia Tardick lizard snuggly labeled 'Asteria'. Her head, face, both
eyes, neck, both wrists, both hands, and waist are left uncovered.
She is carrying nothing.
Lily Kaise wraps her arms around you, pulling you close.

ftl accord
A handful of lonely beacons watch over this area of space, their lights glowing
palely in the dark, surrounded by tendrils of drifting dust and debris.
A planet once existed here, until it was destroyed by the Outsiders. Now only
large chunks of the planet remain, still drifting slowly away from each other,
with clouds of debris filling the sector.
move
The starship is already moving.
A circular space station dominates this sector, made of darkened metal
reinforced against attack. By the look of it, this is probably the most heavily
armored station in human space, excepting The Torus. This is the heart of the
Accord of Free Worlds.

ftl new
Providence Station shines brightly in the dark, one of the few stations that
bothers to illuminate its outer hull. The gleaming hull of the station is bathed
with bright white floodlights.
New Earth rotates through space before you, a startingly verdant planet, colored
in greens and blues with pure white clouds.

Schroeder! Welcome to home space!"

i
 You are wearing a soft red heather cotton polo, a pair of slim black linen
trousers, and a pair of gray canvas sneakers. Underneath this, you are wearing a
pair of white cotton briefs. You are also wearing a keychain, a metallic gold
touch einrophone in a black leather phone holster, a gold wrist-mounted
chronometer, a metallic silver metachannel FTL communicator, a solid silver ring
engraved with dolphins, a backpack, and a bulky asteroid supply cannon. You are
concealing a flight control scanner, a leather briefcase, a camera bag, a thick
synthleather bandolier with large pockets, a black flightbag with a red shooting
star on the side, a golden Feng Wo coin purse, a black engineering tool case, a
large expandable telescoping xenology container, and a scorched metal thigh
holster. Your head, face, both eyes, neck, both elbows, both forearms, both
wrists, and both hands are left uncovered.
You are carrying nothing.

l
[Starship "Blanche Schroeder"; Engineering Room]
The engineering room is much cleaner and sterile than most people expect when
they first board a starship. Though there are some exposed, thick bundles of
wires running here and there, most of the actual workings of the ship are deeper
in its structure. Instead, the room is virtually bare and brightly lit, with one
wall dominated by a large graphical representation of the ship and its
components, alongside current estimates of damage levels. On the right is a
small starmap set into a wall, displaying a bare minimum of information so that
it is not a distraction to the one keeping the ship together. A simple control
board allows the operator to prioritize repairs. The status lights overhead are
currently not receiving power. Looking through the windows, you see that the
ship is in a garage.
You see an improved temporary wormhole drive and a large leather chair here.
You can go up and down.

for a submission from a battle analysis scanner on League Battle-Scanning
Nuclear Temporary Station involving the five-person A.S.S. tactical platform

green
You lift a small plastic cover and press a green button.
You hear a single beep and glance up to see green lights flick on overhead as
the ship enters normal status.
A low hum you had barely noticed until now slowly fades away as weapons are
powered down.
l
[Starship "Blanche Schroeder"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. Lights
overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows,
you see that the ship is in space.
You see a decoy beacon launcher, a wormhole drive tracer, and a black leather
captain's chair here.
You can go south and out.
(You are sitting on a black leather captain's chair.)
Damien Goss strides in from the south.
'Nice.
You say, "Nice."
Damien Goss says in a Malagasy accent, "Thanks. That's all I can do though."
'ok
You say, "Ok."
pa Thanks.
You speak into the microphone.
vector e
You must switch to autopilot before engaging AutoVector.
Johann Rowan's voice comes over the loudspeaker and says, "No problem."
auto

to the word MANUAL switches off.
vector e
You make a selection on the AutoVector control board.
Johann Rowan walks in from the south.
Damien Goss says in a Malagasy accent, "Nice flying."
'Thanks

Damien Goss asks in a Malagasy accent, "What did you put on this thing anyway?"
pa Anyone else out besides Damien?

Don't Know What's Going On Gun The Fastest?" has jumped out of the sector.
The computer reports that the scout "I Watch It For The Music" has jumped out of
the sector.
The computer reports that the three-person A.S.S. destroyer "Carmen Hobbs" has
jumped out of the sector.

switch to chains. It eats up grid with six lasers."
The starship transitions into another sector.

"Greetings. There are currently no active decoy beacons in surrounding sectors."
'I put hyperion eletronic warfare fighters.

however many you wan do."
Providence Station shines brightly in the dark, one of the few stations that
bothers to illuminate its outer hull. The gleaming hull of the station is bathed
with bright white floodlights.
Johann Rowan stumbles, then falls heavily to the floor.
New Earth rotates through space before you, a startingly verdant planet, colored
in greens and blues with pure white clouds.
Via general sector communication, New Earth transmits, "Hello there, Blanche
Schroeder! Welcome to home space!"

of an intact hull plate, two of a hydraulic assembly, a fractured processing
unit, three of an interior panel, and three of an unidentifiable starship
component from an exploding starship.
You earn 5,000,000.00 AEU credits for a successful beacon drop, plus a kill
bonus of 3,375,000.00 AEU credits, plus an enemy magnitude bonus of 1,000,000.00
AEU credits.
You earn a bonus of 3,671,875.00 AEU credits for submitting information to a
battle analysis scanner on a temporary space station.
468,750.00 credits of your income have gone toward your organization.
[Notification from Starseekers] The organization has gained 6,889,040.47 credits
for a submission from a battle analysis scanner on League Battle-Scanning
Nuclear Temporary Station involving the five-person pulsar "Critical Strike".
green
You lift a small plastic cover and press a green button.
You hear a single beep and glance up to see green lights flick on overhead as
the ship enters normal status.
A low hum you had barely noticed until now slowly fades away as weapons are
powered down.

Rogue Romano's voice comes over the loudspeaker and says, "I'm done for now."
The starship transitions into another sector.

"Greetings. There are currently no active decoy beacons in surrounding sectors."
Rogue Romano slinks in from the south.

hiss of hydraulics.

ftl new
Johann Rowan's voice comes over the loudspeaker and says, "Only thing left is
hull damage."
Providence Station shines brightly in the dark, one of the few stations that
bothers to illuminate its outer hull. The gleaming hull of the station is bathed
with bright white floodlights.
New Earth rotates through space before you, a startingly verdant planet, colored
in greens and blues with pure white clouds.
Via general sector communication, New Earth transmits, "Hello there, Critical
Strike! Welcome to home space!"
You hear a brief high-pitched hum as the engineer effects swift repair of a
component.

l
[Starship "Critical Strike"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a decoy beacon launcher, a steel plaque engraved with the phrase
"Reminder: This ship is equipped with a sensor dampening array.", a wormhole
drive tracer, a black leather captain's chair, a dark red leather captain's
chair, a black leather sofa, and a hairy yellow eight-legged ArachnoPal named
Higgins here.
Lily Kaise is standing here.
You can go south and out.

FTL Interalliance Communications Network

Subject: salvage, hopefully final discussion for a bit
Author: Melinda Michaels
Posted: 00:57 25 August 2316 GST
--
So, I was checking the lifespan of these stations and see that stuff is going
down soon at 134. For the following reasons I would like us to try out 285 for
awhile.
1. It is a shorter flight and will hopefully cut down on new pilots getting into
jams with hostiles and falling asleep on the sometimes longer travel time.
2. While you get more points with starship debris, people seem to salvage the
roids and commets faster. Thus, would have more time to close the gap between
the two sets of earned points.
3. When we do salvage ops, they will most likely be at 285 anyway.
4. Pilots who cannot salvage the grade 50 debris can always go out of Orion or
earn industry in other ways.
5. There is an artifact spot at battle of mir in which we can set up a marker
beacon to aid in travel needs.
Thanks everybody who participated in the testing and even confusing discussion
pertaining to this station question. If you all have gripes, questions or
whatever, look me up.
Melinda
--

[Starship "William Dove"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. The
status lights overhead are currently not receiving power. Looking through the
windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a sleek metal quantum entanglement communication device, a rattan floor
lamp with a light purple lotus shade (casting a white-colored glow), a wormhole
drive tracer, a dark purple leather captain's chair, a large oval white and
black cloth rug, a rare black EAOSian contoured couch with a hand-made white and
sapphire star quilt on it, a glossy purple ceramic felo chow bowl, a wall-sized
bubbling neon purple-lit aquarium containing yellow and violet aquatic life and
coral rocks, a small yellow ball containing a realistic Bari horde noisemaker, a
small white trash bin, a purple photocopier, a round white rattan coffee table
with a glass top, a compact red refrigerator, Purr the humanoid service robot,
and a hairy yellow eight-legged ArachnoPal named Higgins here.
Lily Kaise is standing here.
You can go south and out.

The computer reports that the two-person light transport "Registered Merchant

Lily Kaise presses a button and brings up the FTL flight control board.
A pair of odd-colored stars, one green and one blue, mark this curious area of
space. The sensors are picking up odd bits of noise that the ship's computer
insists on trying to convert to audio. Once in a while, something that could
almost sound like a word emerges from a burst of static.
The computer reports that in-sector beacons are transmitting the following:
Rrs/rT}9M6xI29\lUMEEE,5<q+C(EXN0:H|(@6F%
This area of space is within the green belt of the nearest star, but there are
no life-bearing planets here. Instead there is merely an odd cluster of space
stations of unknown origin.
The sensor noise is much worse here, with a constant dark, gutteral snarling
sound emanating from the ship's speakers. It almost sounds like a language, but
it's nothing you've ever heard before, and the ship's computer cannot pinpoint a
source.
Via general sector communication, Beacon E-02 transmits in a robotic voice,
"Detecting vessel 'RockIt!.' Welcome to The Belt of Orion."
Lily Kaise presses a button and brings up the FTL flight control board.
Lily Kaise transfers a toll payment to a local rift accelerator.
[Notification from Starseekers] The organization has received 1,907,228.19 EAOS
credits from a toll payment to League Rift Accelerating Solar Toll Station in
The Belt of Orion.
The computer announces, "Setting course to Asteroid Beacon Alpha 285. Local rift
accelerator with matching vector found."
Something deep inside the starship roars to life as the lights dim sharply.
A wormhole suddenly appears in front of the ship, its edges tinged an unusual
deep purple. Strange undulating shapes are half-visible deep inside it.
A thick undulating mist suddenly seems to rush toward the starship from every
direction, quickly blotting out the stars. Random shapes, some half-familiar,
occasionally form in the mist only to disappear almost immediately.
cuddle lily
You cuddle up to Lily Kaise.
The formless shifting void gradually acquires a regular crest and fall until,
after several moments, you suddenly realize you are on a wide expanse of ocean.
Tall wooden masts creak above you, and white canvas sails snap in the breeze.

"Ishi Wo Tateru Koto". The organization has earned 733,753.72 credits.
Lily Kaise exclaims in a New Earth accent, "Even so, it's easy money!"
nod
You nod.
wrap lily
You wrap your arms around Lily Kaise, pulling her close.
Lily Kaise wraps her arms around you, pulling you close.
Lily Kaise glances at the computer's current coordinates display.
-lily And I get to spend time with you.
The computer reports that the two-person hardened asteroid hauler "Ishi Wo
Tateru Koto" has launched from AEU Asteroid Processing Nuclear Message Beacon;
Docking Bay.
You say to Lily, "And I get to spend time with you."
shis
I don't understand that.
ships
Starships In Sector:
Ishi Wo Tateru Koto.....................(10, 12, 11)
Lily Kaise presses some buttons on the communication board.
Via general sector communication, this ship transmits a text-based transmission:
"beep beep"
scan
Ships in this sector:
[1] Ishi Wo Tateru Koto (League)
Scan which ship?
[Type a line of input or `@abort' to abort the command.]
Via general sector communication, Ishi Wo Tateru Koto transmits a standard
signal: "Greetings."
1
A few green lights blink on, then off again a moment later, as another starship
is scanned.  The computer then displays the following:
CMX-303-AS Coalition Hardened Asteroid Hauler "Ishi Wo Tateru Koto"
--
IFF Transponder Code: League
Model Designation: CMX-303-AS
Hull damage: 0%
Average damage: 0%
Occupancy: Unfilled
FTL Capable: Yes
Weapons: Powered down
Power: Charged
Cargo: None
Coordinates: (10, 12, 11)
Distance: 1
--
Lily Kaise laughs.
grin
You grin.
Lily Kaise glances at the computer's current coordinates display.
Lily Kaise makes a selection on the AutoVector control board.
The computer reports that the two-person hardened asteroid hauler "Ishi Wo
Tateru Koto" has left the sector.
Lily Kaise activates the long-range scanner and searches for passive detections
and recent ping returns.
You hear a "ping" sound as the ship's computer detects an active sensor sweep.
The sound seems overwhelmingly loud.
The starship transitions into another sector.
Lily Kaise says in a New Earth accent, "I think it's Akemi."
The computer reports the presence of an asteroid.
Lily Kaise laughs.
Lily Kaise presses a button to cancel the current autopilot program.
Proper in-sector coordinates not reached.  AutoVector program aborted.
Lily Kaise presses a button and brings up the starship's navigation controls.
A destination appears on the ship's navigation controls: Asteroid (nearest).
'I think so too
You say, "I think so too."
Lily Kaise says in a New Earth accent, "She went west."
kiss lily on lips
You kiss Lily Kaise on the lips.
Lily Kaise kisses you on the lips.
Lily Kaise places a plain white spacesuit helmet atop her head.
You feel mild acceleration as the ship descends toward an asteroid.
Lily Kaise scrambles to her feet.
Lily Kaise glides out.
wear helm
You place a gold spacesuit helmet atop your head.
stand
You stand up from a large purple and lavender paisley floor pillow with thick
gold fringe.
out
[Starship "RockIt!"; Airlock]
Lily Kaise is standing here.
You can go out and enter into the ship.
cycle
You press a large button marked CYCLE.
The computer announces, "Beginning cycling."
A small light on the airlock control panel turns from green to yellow. Through
your suit, you hear the hiss of air quickly leaving the airlock.
out
You may not leave the airlock while it is cycling.
The hiss of air slowly fades away into nothingness, and the yellow light becomes
red.
out
You exit the ship.
[Rocky Asteroid Surface]
The two-person hardened asteroid hauler "RockIt!" is parked here.
You can go north, south, east, west, northeast, northwest, southeast, and
southwest.
Lily Kaise exits from the two-person hardened asteroid hauler "RockIt!".
w
[Rocky Asteroid Surface]
You can go north, south, east, west, northeast, northwest, southeast, and
southwest.
use cannon
You raise a bulky asteroid supply cannon to your eye and begin carefully aiming
at the asteroid's surface through the scope.
(15 seconds roundtime.)
After a few careful seconds aligning everything in the scope, it flashes the
okay to fire. You pull the trigger and an anchor shoots rapidly from the barrel
of a bulky asteroid supply cannon! You lift off the asteroid's surface slightly,
landing as the anchor finishes securing itself.
use cannon
You raise a bulky asteroid supply cannon to your eye and begin carefully aiming
at a single-use asteroid anchor through the scope.
(38 seconds roundtime.)
The scope flashes the okay to fire. You pull the trigger and a ribbon shoots
from the barrel to automatically secure itself to a single-use asteroid anchor
with an attached line.
e
[Rocky Asteroid Surface]
The two-person hardened asteroid hauler "RockIt!" is parked here.
You can go north, south, east, west, northeast, northwest, southeast, and
southwest.

ship. Hopefully it will hold.

cycle

l
[Starship "RockIt!"; Airlock]
You see a large PANEL of environmental controls here. Lights overhead indicate
that the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows, you see that the
ship is at Rocky Asteroid Surface. The hatch appears to be locked. A small,
gently pulsing red light near the hatch marks that the airlock currently
possesses a hostile environment.
Lily Kaise is standing here.
You can go out and enter into the ship.
A small light on the airlock control panel turns from red to yellow. Through
your suit, you gradually begin to hear the hiss of air entering the airlock.
The hiss of air slowly fades away into nothingness, and the yellow light becomes
green.
enter
[Starship "RockIt!"; Control Room]
You see a small lavender trash bin, a large purple and lavender paisley floor
pillow with thick gold fringe, a large white and dusky pink paisley floor pillow
with thick silver fringe, a small oval turquoise rattan table with a glass top,
a compact red refrigerator, a black plastic tray of spider chow, and a Tardick
lizard named Asteria here.
You can go up and out.
Lily Kaise just entered the ship.
remove helm
You remove a gold spacesuit helmet from your head.
Lily Kaise presses a button to deploy the ship's anchor.
A sharp crack is heard throughout the ship as the anchors on either side deploy
with explosive force, biting deep into the surface of the asteroid.
sit pillow
You sit down on a large purple and lavender paisley floor pillow with thick gold
fringe.
The ship's engines fire, and the anchored asteroid gradually begins to move
toward AEU Asteroid Processing Nuclear Message Beacon.
The computer reports that the asteroid is approximately one sector from its
destination.

heads for the docking bay.
You receive 26,633,360.23 AEU credits for this asteroid!
Your income is deferred until the temporary station's storage module is
transferred to a spaceport.

use cannon

at the asteroid's surface through the scope.

After a few careful seconds aligning everything in the scope, it flashes the
okay to fire. You pull the trigger and an anchor shoots rapidly from the barrel
of a bulky asteroid supply cannon! You lift off the asteroid's surface slightly,
landing as the anchor finishes securing itself.

[Starship "RockIt!"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. Lights
overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows,
you see that the ship is at Metal-rich Asteroid Surface.
You see a small lavender trash bin, a large purple and lavender paisley floor
pillow with thick gold fringe, a large white and dusky pink paisley floor pillow
with thick silver fringe, a small oval turquoise rattan table with a glass top,
a compact red refrigerator, a black plastic tray of spider chow, and a Tardick
lizard named Asteria here.
Lily Kaise is standing here.
You can go up and out.
(You are sitting on a large purple and lavender paisley floor pillow with thick
gold fringe.)

destination.

[Starship "RockIt!"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. Lights
overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows,
you see that the ship is at Metal-rich Asteroid Surface.
You see a small lavender trash bin, a large purple and lavender paisley floor
pillow with thick gold fringe, a large white and dusky pink paisley floor pillow
with thick silver fringe, a small oval turquoise rattan table with a glass top,
a compact red refrigerator, a black plastic tray of spider chow, and a Tardick
lizard named Asteria here.
Lily Kaise is sitting on a large purple and lavender paisley floor pillow.
You can go up and out.
(You are sitting on a large purple and lavender paisley floor pillow with thick
gold fringe.)

heads for the docking bay.

transferred to a spaceport.

of a bulky asteroid supply cannon! You lift off the asteroid's surface slightly,
landing as the anchor finishes securing itself.

shoots out to automatically secure itself to a single-use asteroid anchor with

ship. Hopefully it will hold.

Something deep inside the starship roars to life as the lights dim sharply.
A wormhole suddenly appears in front of the ship, its edges tinged an unusual
deep purple. Strange undulating shapes are half-visible deep inside it.
A thick undulating mist suddenly seems to rush toward the starship from every
direction, quickly blotting out the stars. Random shapes, some half-familiar,
occasionally form in the mist only to disappear almost immediately.
The starship has left a unique area of space.
Mist swirls through the air, coalescing into intricate silken webs that coat
every surface.

[Starship "William Dove"; Living Quarters One]
This is a small room designed to give crew members a place to sleep while on
long journeys, and it isn't large enough to do much else. A long counter is
bolted to the wall opposite the entryway, and two narrow bunks have been bolted
to the two remaining walls. A small keypad is next to the door, controlling a
simple lock. The status lights overhead are currently not receiving power.
Looking through the windows, you see that the ship is in a garage.
You see a glossy sapphire blue ceramic felo chow bowl, a small yellow ball
containing a realistic Bari horde noisemaker, a small seashell pink trash can, a
white four poster rattan bed with a heart-shaped headboard and filmy deep purple
hangings with a set of lavender silk sheets, a soft periwinkle cashmere blanket,
a large periwinkle bed pillow, a large periwinkle bed pillow, and a hand-made
purple and amethyst flower quilt on it, a large oval dark purple and light
purple cloth rug, and a small oval turquoise rattan table with a glass top here.
Lily Kaise is dozing on a white four poster rattan bed.
You can go out.
(You are lying on a white four poster rattan bed with a heart-shaped headboard
and filmy deep purple hangings with a set of lavender silk sheets, a soft
periwinkle cashmere blanket, a large periwinkle bed pillow, a large periwinkle
bed pillow, and a hand-made purple and amethyst flower quilt on it.)

ftl accord
A handful of lonely beacons watch over this area of space, their lights glowing
palely in the dark, surrounded by tendrils of drifting dust and debris.
A planet once existed here, until it was destroyed by the Outsiders. Now only
large chunks of the planet remain, still drifting slowly away from each other,
with clouds of debris filling the sector.
A circular space station dominates this sector, made of darkened metal
reinforced against attack. By the look of it, this is probably the most heavily
armored station in human space, excepting The Torus. This is the heart of the
Accord of Free Worlds.
Via general sector communication, Accord of Free Worlds Command transmits,
"Hello, Shooting Star. Welcome to Accord space."

a reactor on there."

transport "Invaders Spare Parts" and carefully float inside, orienting yourself

field.

fission breeder reactor module (contributed by Starseekers)) out of the open bay
door.

l lifter
a space lifter (attached to a quantum salvage processor module (contributed by
Business Cats))
This appears to be similar to a hovering pallet frontloader frequently seen
around spaceports. This model, according to several symbols etched into its
side, is rated for vacuum and zero gravity.

peer out

[Accord of Free Worlds Command; Docking Bay Three]
This is a fully modern docking bay, made of the same sleek, slightly darkened
metal that the exterior of the station is made from. Brightly painted yellow
lines mark entry and exit paths for ships, and rows of dotted lines indicate
where ships may touch down. A series of electromagnetic manipulators prevent
atmosphere from escaping into space when the bay door is opened. A few of the
lines here are painted blue instead of yellow, and seem to be reserved for
emergency traffic. A ramp leads up to the rest of the station.
The two-person Accord space module scout "Help Us Small Modules", the
four-person Accord space module transport "Temp Station Condensation", the
four-person Accord space module transport "Segue", and the four-person Accord
space module transport "Just Dropping In" are landed here.
You can go southeast, southwest, and up.
launch
The navigation systems are nonfunctional until their power is restored.
tra 1 Ok, Lily. I'll undock. Hang on.
[AEU | 1: Alliance Communication] Shule Elemmire transmits, "Ok, Lily. I'll
undock. Hang on."
power
You grasp a large lever on the control board and push it slowly away from you.
Status lights blink on all around you as faint hums and beeps begin to emanate
from the various starship systems.
launch
You use the ship's radio to ask flight control for launch clearance.
Flight control gives the ship launch clearance.
ships
There are no other ships in the sector.

[1] The Shoulder of Orion (Unclaimed)
[2] The Belt of Orion (Unclaimed)
Enter your selection:
2
A pair of odd-colored stars, one green and one blue, mark this curious area of
space. The sensors are picking up odd bits of noise that the ship's computer
insists on trying to convert to audio. Once in a while, something that could
almost sound like a word emerges from a burst of static.
The computer reports that in-sector beacons are transmitting the following:
/k7l6y9Tw|`VFEY`&gZs-ZSWmd($"pTXKaok3^GZ
This area of space is within the green belt of the nearest star, but there are
no life-bearing planets here. Instead there is merely an odd cluster of space
stations of unknown origin.
The sensor noise is much worse here, with a constant dark, gutteral snarling
sound emanating from the ship's speakers. It almost sounds like a language, but
it's nothing you've ever heard before, and the ship's computer cannot pinpoint a
source.
Via general sector communication, Beacon E-02 transmits in a robotic voice,
"Detecting vessel 'Starseeker's Beacon.' Welcome to The Belt of Orion."
ftl 285

you wish to pay this?

y
You transfer a toll payment to a local rift accelerator.
[Notification from Starseekers] The organization has received 1,907,198.08 EAOS
credits from a toll payment to League Rift Accelerating Solar Toll Station in
The Belt of Orion.
The computer announces, "Setting course to Asteroid Beacon Alpha 285. Local rift
accelerator with matching vector found."
Something deep inside the starship roars to life as the lights dim sharply.
A wormhole suddenly appears in front of the ship, its edges tinged an unusual
deep purple. Strange undulating shapes are half-visible deep inside it.
A thick undulating mist suddenly seems to rush toward the starship from every
direction, quickly blotting out the stars. Random shapes, some half-familiar,
occasionally form in the mist only to disappear almost immediately.
The computer beeps in an imperative manner and informs you that the starship's
sensors have detected a new location of interest in the riftflow.
The computer beeps in an imperative manner and informs you that the starship's
sensors have detected a new location of interest in the riftflow.
Mist swirls through the air, coalescing into intricate silken webs that coat
every surface.
The computer beeps in an imperative manner and informs you that the starship's
sensors have detected a new location of interest in the riftflow.

deep purple. Strange undulating shapes are half-visible deep inside it.
A thick undulating mist suddenly seems to rush toward the starship from every
direction, quickly blotting out the stars. Random shapes, some half-familiar,
occasionally form in the mist only to disappear almost immediately.

sensors have detected a new location of interest in the riftflow.
The swirling mist parts to reveal a gaping mouth! Before you can react, the ship
has plunged into it and into a fleshy pink tunnel.

sensors have detected a new location of interest in the riftflow.

A handful of lonely beacons watch over this area of space, their lights glowing
palely in the dark, surrounded by tendrils of drifting dust and debris.
A planet once existed here, until it was destroyed by the Outsiders. Now only
large chunks of the planet remain, still drifting slowly away from each other,
with clouds of debris filling the sector.

armored station in human space, excepting The Torus. This is the heart of the
Accord of Free Worlds.

elicits a feeling of "home" in almost all who view it, even if they have never
actually set foot on it.
The computer reports that the two-person Accord gemini "Gtr Beni Gittiin
Yere" has landed on the planet Old Earth.

issue. No one ever said cans need to be full to the rim when you turn them in."

Star! Welcome to Old Earth Orbit!"

nearest holovid, where the image of a ship can be seen landing on the outside
landing pad. An informative bit of text below it identifies it as the two-person
medium transport "Registered Merchant 285".

travel by rift while you have that glow? Any idea how long your experiment will
run?"

2
A pair of odd-colored stars, one green and one blue, mark this curious area of
space. The sensors are picking up odd bits of noise that the ship's computer
insists on trying to convert to audio. Once in a while, something that could
almost sound like a word emerges from a burst of static.
The computer reports that in-sector beacons are transmitting the following:
(me<_*$EE%"I<)@L`"0\9Gi9F5Am2|\&SxzJ8wlv
This area of space is within the green belt of the nearest star, but there are
no life-bearing planets here. Instead there is merely an odd cluster of space
stations of unknown origin.
The sensor noise is much worse here, with a constant dark, gutteral snarling
sound emanating from the ship's speakers. It almost sounds like a language, but
it's nothing you've ever heard before, and the ship's computer cannot pinpoint a
source.
Via general sector communication, Beacon E-02 transmits in a robotic voice,
"Detecting vessel 'Celestial Explorer.' Welcome to The Belt of Orion."
The computer reports that the two-person medium transport "Cubic Zirconia" has
entered the sector.

wave

l
[Manhattan Spaceport; Pilot Lounge]
Seemingly wedged in the extra space between two other rooms, this lounge is very
narrow but extends far back, giving it enough room to seat quite a few people.
The light from the suspended lamps is warm and easy on the eyes, casting
everything in a rich golden glow, and the booths are padded and comfortable. The
walls are decorated with countless replicas of old flags and yellowing paper
maps of Earth's various countries. A tiny holovid nestled at the far edge of
each booth shows both a view of the landing pad outside and the latest news
broadcasts. There is a stairway at the back of the room that leads to the
garage.
You see a lacquered wooden bar, a public holovid, a small red trash can, a
brightly-lit candy vending machine, and a salt lick here.
Ali Candan is sitting on a cushy booth seat. Kim Saunders, Ted Warburton,
Melinda Michaels, Johann Rowan, and Akemi Bando are standing here.
You can go out.
Ted Warburton laughs.
Kim Saunders waves to you.
Melinda Michaels holds your hand, taking you into her group.
'I'm ready
You say, "I'm ready."
Ted Warburton waves.
The image on the nearest holovid trembles minutely as the image of the
two-person medium transport "Cubic Zirconia" launches from the outside landing
pad and rises into space.
Ali Candan scrambles to his feet.
Ali Candan strides out.
The image on the nearest holovid trembles minutely as the image of the
two-person medium transport "Artik Degil" launches from the outside landing pad
and rises into space.
Melinda Michaels waves to Akemi Bando. "We shall return some time or other."
Kim says to you in a New Bristol accent, "What was actually the problem?"
Akemi Bando speaks into her glittery black metachannel FTL communicator:
[General Communication] Lily Kaise transmits, "So everyone go to Belt of Orion
and I suppose we could go one sector north so I can at least add everyone."
[Tactical Communication] Akemi Bando transmits, "Bari spreader just passed
through starship museum according to the scanner."
"And Hi, Akemi." Kim Saunders smiles. "Sorry, did not mean to ignore you."
'Not entirely sure.
You say, "Not entirely sure."
Akemi Bando waves.
Akemi Bando says in a Japanese accent, "Bari."
Akemi Bando moves out.
Ted Warburton wanders out.
You hear the clank of something being dropped on the landing pad, followed by
loud swearing.
Kim Saunders strolls out.
The image on the nearest holovid trembles minutely as the image of the
two-person medium transport "Medium Slicer" launches from the outside landing
pad and rises into space.
The image on the nearest holovid trembles minutely as the image of the
two-person tugboat "Isseki Nicho" launches from the outside landing pad and
rises into space.
The image on the nearest holovid trembles minutely as the image of the
two-person medium transport "Big Yellow Eagle" launches from the outside landing
pad and rises into space.
Melinda Michaels speaks into her tyrian purple metachannel FTL communicator:
[Tactical Communication] Melinda Michaels transmits, "Is somebody getting after
the bari spreader?"
Johann Rowan says in a German accent, "I can if you don't mind meeting up with
me."
Johann Rowan says in a German accent, "It shouldn't take me that long."
[Tactical Communication] Akemi Bando transmits, "Bari pod in Starship Museum."
Melinda Michaels speaks into her tyrian purple metachannel FTL communicator:
[Tactical Communication] Melinda Michaels transmits, "We need to take care of
this bari situation before we come to defend the op."
[Tactical Communication] Akemi Bando transmits, "Two spreaders in Clarkson's
Push."
Johann Rowan walks out.
[Tactical Communication] Akemi Bando transmits, "One jumped to Jameson's Reach."
A technician wanders in, orders a cup of coffee, then hurries back out with the
steaming beverage.
'Want me to stay here or go?
You ask, "Want me to stay here or go?"
A bit of movement out of the corner of your eye draws your attention to the
nearest holovid, where the image of a ship can be seen landing on the outside
landing pad. An informative bit of text below it identifies it as the two-person
medium transport "Registered Merchant 285".
Melinda says to you in a Bedford accent, "Better go check AEU sectors."
nod
You nod.
'That's what I thought
You say, "That's what I thought."

[New Earth; Piper Wincott Memorial Garage]
Even though this starship garage smells like machine oil and heavy lubricants,
it is spacious and well-lit. Massive hydraulic systems raise and lower starships
to and from the landing pad above, and technicians and mechanics in silvery gray
coveralls ensure that everything keeps running smoothly. A well-lit stairway
which leads to the pilot's lounge is here.

[New Earth; Spaceport Landing Pad]
The busy landing pad of New Earth's capital city's spaceport sits over a large
bay at the tip of the southern continent. The pad itself is a huge square sheet
of white plasteel surrounded by gleaming new starship service structures. On the
southern side of the pad is a circular structure with wide transparisteel
windows affording a fabulous view of the ocean. A softly lit sign over the
transparisteel doorway reads, 'Pilot Lounge,' and a separate doorway is marked
'Liaison Office.' It looks like you can GO into either of those places. To the
west, a bridge spans the gap between the landing pad and the rest of the
spaceport.
You see an automatic teller machine and a small trash can here.
You can go north, south, west, and down.

l
[Starship "Shooting Star"; Control Capsule]
This small capsule is only large enough for one person. A single flight seat
molds itself to the form of its occupant, helping to ease the burden of
acceleration along with a rather underpowered artificial gravity dampening
system. The capsule's inner workings extend into the flight cabin, with the
starship's main computer right up against the back of the seat. A rather sparse
flight control board is presented claustrophobically close to the pilot's face.
It seems to lack any sort of manual control, allowing only automatic flight
profiles to be entered into an antiquated flight computer. It does, however,
possess controls to operate a single small turret. Lights overhead indicate that
the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows, you see that the ship
is at New Earth; Spaceport Landing Pad. The hatch appears to be locked.
You see an improved temporary wormhole drive here.
You can go out.
(You are sitting.)
A voice comes over the speaker and says, "Shooting Star, you have clearance to
launch. Good luck and come back to us safely."

to Old Earth.
Old Earth turns below you, blue and green and brown and white. The planet

actually set foot on it.

[Starship "Raptor"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. Lights
overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows,
you see that the ship is in space.
You see a decoy beacon launcher, an interdictor launcher, and a black leather
captain's chair here.
Melinda Michaels and Johann Rowan are standing here.
You can go south, up, and out.
[Salvage Op] Ted Warburton: "Is the can clear? I now have a load."
[Salvage Op] Melinda Michaels: "Yes."
Melinda Michaels's voice comes over the loudspeaker and says, "Shule, do you
have chaingun resistance in case we get unregs?"
pa I do.
You speak into the microphone.
Melinda Michaels's voice comes over the loudspeaker and says, "Okay."
pa I'm well supplied with every engineering tool avilable.
You speak into the microphone.
Melinda Michaels's voice comes over the loudspeaker and says, "Good."
pa available too.
You speak into the microphone.
[Salvage Op] Ted Warburton: "I missed a sector change somewhere and have to find
it."

[Starship "Raptor"; Engineering Room]
The engineering room is much cleaner and sterile than most people expect when
they first board a starship. Though there are some exposed, thick bundles of
wires running here and there, most of the actual workings of the ship are deeper
in its structure. Instead, the room is virtually bare and brightly lit, with one
wall dominated by a large graphical representation of the ship and its
components, alongside current estimates of damage levels. On the right is a
small starmap set into a wall, displaying a bare minimum of information so that
it is not a distraction to the one keeping the ship together. A simple control
board allows the operator to prioritize repairs. Lights overhead indicate that
the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows, you see that the ship
is in space.
You see an improved temporary wormhole drive, a temporary wormhole drive, an
improved temporary wormhole drive, and a swiveling black leather gunner's chair
here.
You can go north and down.
(You are sitting on a swiveling black leather gunner's chair.)

A pair of odd-colored stars, one green and one blue, mark this curious area of
space. The sensors are picking up odd bits of noise that the ship's computer
insists on trying to convert to audio. Once in a while, something that could
almost sound like a word emerges from a burst of static.
The computer reports that in-sector beacons are transmitting the following:
(_+C:AzS2ta8{JTp\8iekY!o&dIm`Vx!O7l]IlHb
This area of space is within the green belt of the nearest star, but there are
no life-bearing planets here. Instead there is merely an odd cluster of space
stations of unknown origin.
The sensor noise is much worse here, with a constant dark, gutteral snarling
sound emanating from the ship's speakers. It almost sounds like a language, but
it's nothing you've ever heard before, and the ship's computer cannot pinpoint a
source.
Via general sector communication, Beacon E-02 transmits in a robotic voice,
"Detecting vessel 'Firestorm.' Welcome to The Belt of Orion."

l
[Starship "Firestorm"; Control Room]
The control room is the hub of every starship. Large metal conduits protect
thick bundles of wires carrying information from every part of the ship to this
one location. A large transparisteel viewport provides a view out the front of
the ship, but experienced pilots in space will have eyes only for the large
starmap dominating the right side of the room. Standing before the viewport is
the main control board, providing essential functions like the shipwide power
lever and alert status. Secondary control boards can be pulled up and folded
back to provide a working surface, or pulled down from recesses overhead as
needed. Though the room is spacious enough for a few others to sit or stand, the
entire architecture of the room is built around the small space before the
control board and the person who will stand there: the starship's pilot. Lights
overhead indicate that the ship is on green status. Looking through the windows,
you see that the ship is in space.
You see a black leather captain's chair, a decoy beacon launcher, a
bioaugmentation plant in a small pot labeled "Space Invaders", and a wormhole
drive tracer here.
You can go south, up, and out.
(You are sitting on a black leather captain's chair.)
